newsitem.title: USA: Wal-Mart sued for $6 million over race.
newsitem.headline: Wal-Mart sued for $6 million over race.

text.p: A North Carolina woman who worked as a part-time cashier at Wal-Mart Stores Inc, sued the retailer and three of its employees for $6 million on Tuesday, charging race discrimination.
Felicia Gray-Watson, who is black, alleged in her lawsuit that three white workers at the Wal-Mart pharmacy in Knightdale, North Carolina, likened her to a slave.
She is seeking $1 million in compensatory damages and $5 million in punitive damages.

Gray-Watson said that on November 13, she asked pharmacy manager Eddie Cash about making a change to her work schedule. Cash then questioned Gray-Watson on whether she planned to resign her part-time post.

But before Watson could answer the question, assistant manager Donna Newsome interrupted the conversation and said: "Felicia you can't quit. Slaves can't quit. They have to be sold," according to the lawsuit.
Gray-Watson, whose 17-month tenure at the store supported her graduate studies, told a news conference Tuesday that the statment was "personally, racially and culturally degrading."
The lawsuit says Cash and Newsome laughed at the comment and that Cash called another Wal-Mart pharmacy assistant manager, Wanda Crocker, to share the comment.

While still on the telephone, Cash turned to Gray-Watson to share a question from Crocker, according to the lawsuit: "Felicia, Wanda told me to ask you if you knew that there was a slave market in Fayetteville, North Carolina?"
The defendants continued to taunt Gray-Watson, who says the trauma of the racial slurs have since caused her severe headaches, nausea, emotional distress and mental anguish.
